description: From Middle English traunce, from Anglo-Norman transe (“fear of coming evil; passage from life to death”), from transir (“to be numb with fear; to die, pass on”), from Latin trānseō (“to cross over”).

entries.meaning: (countable) A state of awareness, concentration, or focus that filters experience and information (for example, a state of meditation or possession by some being).
examples: And he became very hungry, and would have eaten; but while they made ready, he fell into a trance.

entries.meaning: (countable, psychology) A state of low response to stimulus and diminished, narrow attention; particularly one induced by hypnosis.
(uncountable, music) Short for trance music (“genre of electronic dance music”).

verbs.description: trance (third-person singular simple present trances, present participle trancing, simple past and past participle tranced)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To (cause to) be in a trance; to entrance.
(transitive, rare) To create in or via a trance.
examples: The Horned Toad (kɛŋkak) tranced the rivers into being. A bakɔh bird tranced the mountains. The Scrub Bulbul (ˀɛsˀããs) drilled fire into existence with its beak. And, finally, the Bronzed Black Drongo (tɛrhɛɛh) tranced the year  […]

description: The verb is derived from Middle English traunce, trauncen, trancen (“to move about (?); to prance (?); to trample the ground”) (whence modern English trounce with the same senses, which see for more). The noun is probably derived from the verb.

entries.meaning: (obsolete outside Britain, dialectal) A tedious journey.

verbs.description: trance (third-person singular simple present trances, present participle trancing, simple past and past participle tranced)

entries.meaning: (obsolete outside Britain, dialectal, intransitive) To walk heavily or with some difficulty; to tramp, to trudge.
(obsolete outside Britain, dialectal, intransitive) To pass across or over; to traverse.
(obsolete outside Britain, dialectal, intransitive) To travel quickly over a long distance.
